review: Great performances by both Maggie Smith and Alex Jennings make for a mannered and compelling film who's only real shortfall is the short shrift that the screenwriter Alan Bennett gives his own character. Similar in theme to the more keenly observed Catholic Church as villain film "Willamena", Bennett's role is sometimes underwritten in deference to Smiths'.

Disappointing. Sure, Dame Maggie is very good, but it was all very heavy handed. Billed as a "mostly true story", one wonders which parts are not so true, and one suspects it's the Catholic-bashing bits.

Loved this movie, it has wonderful acting and a story that is so well written, get very tired of the same old movies with nothing but cursing and violence. It is very refreshing to see an honest to goodness real story and actors who bring the characters alive.

Were it not for the performance of Maggie Smith and a resurgent second hour, this film would have been otherwise forgettable. The picture's excessively tedious opening 45 minutes, coupled with an overwritten, gimmicky narrative and an unfocused script that overemphasizes certain elements while slighting others, make it painful to endure, trying the patience of even the most stalwart moviegoer. Wait for this one to come to cable.

Don't judge it by the trailer. This is far more wonderful than that made it look and not just because of Dame Maggie. Had there been better Hollywood releases this weekend I might have missed this. Glad I didn't.

+ "The Lady in the Van" stars Maggie Smith in a trifle English story that has one of the longest drawn out endings I can recall in a long time and the movie is only 103 minutes! She plays a curmudgeon recreating the role she performed on stage written by Alan Bennett who also wrote this screenplay.The story is of an old woman who lives in a van, parking the vehicle in the driveway of the author. Alex Jennings plays the author and his alter ego who fight over art versus life which presents a distraction throughout the film.The film opens with a loud crash on a black screen and then seeing the window of the van cracked and bloody. Little by little we find out who this homeless, aimless lady was and what brought her to this point in her life. We, also, find out about the crash which really adds nothing to the story but does add to the running time as does a piano concert scene.The supporting players are all excellent English actors who add a touch of class including Jim Broadbent, Frances De La Tour, Deborah Findlay, James Corden and Roger Allam."The Lady in the Van" certainly must have been better in the theatre and this film is only for truly devoted Maggie Smith fans.
Saw this last night, an amusing, entertaining and heartwarming film. Not a laugh a minute but wasn't expecting it to be. Some brilliant acting, especially fromMaggie Smith.

Alex Jennings was irritating and bored the pant off me. No doubt an Oscar for Maggie Smith. We left before the end as it was getting on my nerves. Shame because the could have made a smash out of this film.
Wonderful. Smith gives an Oscar-worthy performance, and the movie itself is delightful.

I spent 40 years of my working life in Camden Town and knew all the featured players in the film. Mrs Shepherd was a rancid old bat ,frankly, but we never knew her back story and it's to Bennett's credit that our sympathy is gradually stirred towards her. I can vouch for the authenticity of the staging ,every scene is filmed where it happened and for those of us who were there at the time it's almost unsettling. A marvellous film made with integrity and style.
Such a charming and beautiful film that just made me smile, really good and most see film
If you like her in Downton, you will LOVE her in this. An amazing performance, by Maggie Smith, and an hilarious and touching film. Totally satisfying
Love Maggie (who doesn't?) & this looks like a winner!

A glorious antidote to sickly cliched hollywood borefests, The Lady in the van asks serious questions about age, mental health and property prices in London.The writing of Bennet is as one would expect excellent, appearing to be as sickly sweet at a meringue but with sharp barbs at our perceived understanding of how things should be.The film works as a superb ensemble piece for a raft of excellent British actors and is well shot. Car enthusiasts will enjoy spotting the changing metal on the streets around Bennett's house.Smith however is simply exceptional, proving that in a well written and sensitively directed work good actors can bloom magnificently. Without doubt she deserves a vanful awards for this.There aren't huge guffaw inducing set piece jokes, but more laughs that build before being immediately pricked by a needle of sharp social comment.Yes it tends to veer in the direction of 'Talking Heads' as all of Bennetts work does, but it's none the worse for that. Recommended.
Excellent film, Maggie Smith at her best
Wonderful acting, brilliant writing and great comic timing. A film to see more than once!

Maggie Smith stars as Miss Shepherd, a rude and obnoxious woman with a distinctive odour and an even more distinctive yellow van which also doubles as her place of residence. Shepherd's past is shrouded in mystery and one day she pulls up into a middle class street in a suburb in London and decides that is going to be her place to settle and subjecting the local residents to her unwelcome company in the process. One of those residents is real life author and playwright, Alan Bennett (played by Alex Jennings) whose mundane life is turned upside down when she makes his driveway a permanent fixture for her four wheeled dwelling.The film is supported with a host of British talent from the big and small screen with the likes of Jim Broadbent (Hot Fuzz) and and Frances De La Tour (best known for playing Miss Jones in the 70's sitcom Rising Damp). And this is a very British film, mingling the subject of class with a great deal of pathos and dry humour which Bennett's work is synonymous with.The screening I went to was packed with people from what I like to call the "Silver Dollar" crowd and the inclusion of Maggie Smith will certainly draw them in. However this is a both a moving and touching story as we see the love/hate relationship between Shepherd and Bennett grow and the mystery surrounding Miss Shepherd unravel as the story unfolds.
A charming witty film.

3,5. Based on a true story, "The Lady in the Van" is entirely driven by the memorable performance by Maggie Smith. But perhaps this is another case of a perfomance-being-greater-than-the-actual-film, which could easily be about 30 minutes shorter, because of the lack of creativity and the stillness of the plot.
Totally heartbreaking, somewhat confusing and absolutely lovely. Most certainly the best thing I've seen this year.

Great performances by both Maggie Smith and Alex Jennings make for a mannered and compelling film who's only real shortfall is the short shrift that the screenwriter Alan Bennett gives his own character. Similar in theme to the more keenly observed Catholic Church as villain film "Willamena", Bennett's role is sometimes underwritten in deference to Smiths'.

Disappointing. Sure, Dame Maggie is very good, but it was all very heavy handed. Billed as a "mostly true story", one wonders which parts are not so true, and one suspects it's the Catholic-bashing bits.

Loved this movie, it has wonderful acting and a story that is so well written, get very tired of the same old movies with nothing but cursing and violence. It is very refreshing to see an honest to goodness real story and actors who bring the characters alive.

Were it not for the performance of Maggie Smith and a resurgent second hour, this film would have been otherwise forgettable. The picture's excessively tedious opening 45 minutes, coupled with an overwritten, gimmicky narrative and an unfocused script that overemphasizes certain elements while slighting others, make it painful to endure, trying the patience of even the most stalwart moviegoer. Wait for this one to come to cable.

Don't judge it by the trailer. This is far more wonderful than that made it look and not just because of Dame Maggie. Had there been better Hollywood releases this weekend I might have missed this. Glad I didn't.

Wonderful. Smith gives an Oscar-worthy performance, and the movie itself is delightful.

Well written and excellently acted. A brilliant tale well told and developed fully. Its hard to say who was better in this film Dame Maggie Smith as the "lady" or Alex Jennings as a truly superb Alan Bennett.

I spent 40 years of my working life in Camden Town and knew all the featured players in the film. Mrs Shepherd was a rancid old bat ,frankly, but we never knew her back story and it's to Bennett's credit that our sympathy is gradually stirred towards her. I can vouch for the authenticity of the staging ,every scene is filmed where it happened and for those of us who were there at the time it's almost unsettling. A marvellous film made with integrity and style.
Such a charming and beautiful film that just made me smile, really good and most see film
If you like her in Downton, you will LOVE her in this. An amazing performance, by Maggie Smith, and an hilarious and touching film. Totally satisfying
I soooo want to watch it. :D

Maggie Smith blows you away with a performance that is hard to beat by literally any actress in this era. Delivering laughs & tears throughout, her portrayal of a homeless women is just stunning. Her on-screen chemistry with Alex Jennings is amazing who himself delivers a top double performance to keep up with Smith. A total entertainer.
Love Maggie (who doesn't?) & this looks like a winner!

A glorious antidote to sickly cliched hollywood borefests, The Lady in the van asks serious questions about age, mental health and property prices in London.The writing of Bennet is as one would expect excellent, appearing to be as sickly sweet at a meringue but with sharp barbs at our perceived understanding of how things should be.The film works as a superb ensemble piece for a raft of excellent British actors and is well shot. Car enthusiasts will enjoy spotting the changing metal on the streets around Bennett's house.Smith however is simply exceptional, proving that in a well written and sensitively directed work good actors can bloom magnificently. Without doubt she deserves a vanful awards for this.There aren't huge guffaw inducing set piece jokes, but more laughs that build before being immediately pricked by a needle of sharp social comment.Yes it tends to veer in the direction of 'Talking Heads' as all of Bennetts work does, but it's none the worse for that. Recommended.
Excellent film, Maggie Smith at her best
The only vans worth going to are fastfood vans or ice cream vans - this van was neither...
Wonderful acting, brilliant writing and great comic timing. A film to see more than once!
A strange film about a strange old woman.

Maggie Smith stars as Miss Shepherd, a rude and obnoxious woman with a distinctive odour and an even more distinctive yellow van which also doubles as her place of residence. Shepherd's past is shrouded in mystery and one day she pulls up into a middle class street in a suburb in London and decides that is going to be her place to settle and subjecting the local residents to her unwelcome company in the process. One of those residents is real life author and playwright, Alan Bennett (played by Alex Jennings) whose mundane life is turned upside down when she makes his driveway a permanent fixture for her four wheeled dwelling.The film is supported with a host of British talent from the big and small screen with the likes of Jim Broadbent (Hot Fuzz) and and Frances De La Tour (best known for playing Miss Jones in the 70's sitcom Rising Damp). And this is a very British film, mingling the subject of class with a great deal of pathos and dry humour which Bennett's work is synonymous with.The screening I went to was packed with people from what I like to call the "Silver Dollar" crowd and the inclusion of Maggie Smith will certainly draw them in. However this is a both a moving and touching story as we see the love/hate relationship between Shepherd and Bennett grow and the mystery surrounding Miss Shepherd unravel as the story unfolds.

Mostly funny, sometimes hilarious, it's as if the role was written purely for Maggie Smith. Sometimes sad. A poignant film on the invisibility of single, elderly, forgotten folk who may have an interesting back story but are often written off as "crazy old....." Do go and see this - and then count how many actors show up from The History Boys !

While you will not be disappointed if you come to see Maggie Smith acts her filthy hobo socks off on screen; the film is about her Miss Shepherd as much as it is about Alan Bennett who let her and her van sit in his driveway for 15 years. So instead, I am going to praise the rather amazing Alex Jennings who plays him. The film script opens up the story by having 2 Bennetts talk to each other. It is an intriguing and effective narrative device that not only delivers some of the best lines in the film, but also avoids having him talk to himself in an artificial and somewhat theatrical manner and we get so much more from this inverted monologue as to who Bennett is: as an insecure writer, a closeted son caring for his mother and a compassionate person who just wants to help. Add on a few "Historical" cameos and a bittersweet ending that is befitting the lady in question, you get a cozy and often thoughtful film that verges on sentimentality but never dwells on it.
A charming witty film.

3,5. Based on a true story, "The Lady in the Van" is entirely driven by the memorable performance by Maggie Smith. But perhaps this is another case of a perfomance-being-greater-than-the-actual-film, which could easily be about 30 minutes shorter, because of the lack of creativity and the stillness of the plot.
excellent performance by magie smith , funny , sad and all round great movie
Got to be honest, I did nod off at the start, but it got better as it went along! Maggie Smith will always be a legend!
Totally heartbreaking, somewhat confusing and absolutely lovely. Most certainly the best thing I've seen this year.
Very good film - Alan Bennett's observations about life and people are so entertaining and of course Maggie Smith is world class.
Cantankerous, amusing, amazingly bittersweet Maggie Smith may claim her third statuette --in custard yellow. This little work of art is an absolute must.
Highly entertaining and very funny yet poignant and emotive. Maggie Smith acts a tour de force here and deserves huge praise for her performance as the feisty old lady..
Charming lovely and ever so funny. Maggie Smith delights in the true story of a lady who moves into Alan Bennetts drive and stays for 15 years. Its so well written and utterly watchable SUPERB!
A nice wee film if you have an hour or two to spare. Easy watching, slowly paced, not bad.

To say that Maggie Smith is like a quiet hurricane in this is an understatement, she shines as the cantankerous old lady in that van. Her backstory is drip fed to the audience and its not until the final scene you know why she is living the life she does, although some of you would've already guessed. It is a film that I will probably only watch the once as it does end bittersweet, but that's not to say there aren't any funny moments, there are and it doesn't resort to American Pie style gross out gags. Its a great film that has some poignant moments but it is a film to watch the once. I'm sure it will be nominated for a lot of Best Actress awards though and maybe a nod for Alex Jennings as he does play a good role as Alan Bennett.

A character study of a woman whose character and circumstances are so peculiar that you couldn't credibly make it up. Not particularly funny or comical, but has strong acting from all the characters, and a story that is told in a "matter of fact" style.
this film looks really funny
FUCK YEAH MAGGIE SLAY
Maggie Smith once again shows every other actor in the world how it's done. An utter delight, moving, funny, touching and delicious from beginning to end.
I would like see that with my mom This Christmas!!!!
Maggie Smith is NOT TO BE MISSED... astounding
Maggie Smith is so good
